If we subtract from a real number $x$ the greatest integer not exceeding
$x$, we obtain a number $y$ between 0 and 1, which can equal 0 if $x$ is
an integer. In other , $$y \;=\; x\!-\!\lfloor{x}\rfloor,$$ where
$\lfloor{x}\rfloor$ is the floor of $x$. Such a number $y$ is called the
[*mantissa*]{} of $x$. So we have for example\
$2.7-2 \;=\; 0.7$,\
$1.7-1 \;=\; 0.7$,\
$0.7-0 \;=\; 0.7$,\
$-0.3\!-\!(-1) = 0.7$,\
$-1.3\!-\!(-2) = 0.7,$\
i.e. these numbers 2.7, 1.7, 0.7, $-0.3$, $-1.3$ at mutual distances an
integer have the same mantissa (0.7). This is apparently always true —
thus the [*mantissa function*]{} $$x \mapsto x\!-\!\lfloor{x}\rfloor$$
is : its is 1.\
The mantissa is identic with the mantissa used in the Briggsian
logarithm calculations.\
When $x$ increases from an integer $n$ towards the next integer
$n\!+\!1$, its mantissa $x\!-\!\lfloor{x}\rfloor$ increases with the
same speed from 0 tending to 1, but at $n\!+\!1$ it falls back to 0.
